text:
"Of course, I’m a fool," he said, looking gloomy, "but you’re just as bad."

"No, brother, I’m not like you at all. I’m not thinking of anything silly."

They walked in silence, and when they got close to Raskolnikov’s place, Razumihin broke the quiet, sounding worried.

"Listen," he said, "you’re a great guy, but you have some problems. I know you’re a bit of a mess and not very clean. You’re weak and nervous, getting lazy and can’t resist anything—and that’s not good because it leads you down a bad path. You’ve let yourself go so much that I don’t know how you’re still a good doctor. You—a doctor—sleep in a comfy bed and only get up at night for your patients! In a few years, you won’t even get up for them… But that’s not the main point! You’re staying in the landlady’s flat tonight. (It took a lot to convince her!) And I’ll be in the kitchen. So this is your chance to get to know her better… It’s not what you think! There’s nothing like that, brother…!"

"But I’m not thinking anything!"

"You have modesty, silence, shyness, a kind of wild goodness… and yet she’s sighing and softening like wax, just melting! Help me get away from her, please! She’s very charming… I’ll repay you, I’ll do anything…."

Zossimov laughed harder than ever.

"Well, you’re in love! But what am I supposed to do with her?"

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin expresses concern about Raskolnikov's deteriorating state and encourages him to connect with a woman who may help him.
